est un parcours: is a course that students can choose following the first year of the Law Degree which constitutes the common core of the Bachelor studies. The License in Public Law offers students training in the various disciplines of public law: constitutional, administrative, financial and international law. These essential subjects for the training of any publicist form the group of compulsory subjects. To allow students to deepen the discipline in one or another particular aspect, a variety of optional subjects are offered to them throughout their undergraduate studies. In addition, all students must take transversal language and human rights courses. The License in Public Law allows students to apply for professional Masters and to take the various competitions which require the License in Law.
Conditions d'accès à la formation et pré: Conditions of access to training and prerequisites
Baccalauréat: Baccalaureate Letters mainly and other Baccalaureates.
La Licence en droit public: The License in Public Law allows students to apply for professional Masters and to take the various competitions which require the License in Law (ENA, Administrative Court, Court of Auditors, Foreign Affairs, etc.).
Formation initiale, Formation continue,: Initial training, Continuing training, Work-study training
Première année Licence unifiée en Droit: First year Unified License in Law
Droit constitutionnel 2:Regime politique: Constitutional law 2: Political regime and Tunisian political regime
Deuxième année Licence unifiée en Droit: Second year Unified License in Law
Troixieme année Licence fondamentale en: Third year Basic degree in Public Law
Descriptif des stages et des activités p: Description of internships and practical end-of-study activities
Inter liaisons entre les semestres du pa: Inter links between the semesters of the course, gateways (to be specified), evaluation and progression
Le premier: The first and second are reserved for common modules: basic license in private law and fundamental license in public law. The options are mandatory. The third, fourth, fifth and sixth semesters are reserved for specialization; It is within this framework that specific topics in public law are dealt with. It should be noted that the six-semester program complies with the recommendations of the Sectorial Law Commission.
